pull.title: ctime_test: move context randomization test to the end
pull.body: I noticed this while reviewing https://github.com/ElementsProject/secp256k1-zkp/pull/117 and  finding some seemingly unnecessary `VALGRIND_MAKE_MEM_DEFINED` that I couldn't remove until I saw the bug.

repo.name: secp256k1
repo.description: Optimized C library for EC operations on curve secp256k1

events.body: ah, indeed the comment said it needed to be last. :)  Did you look into why it wasn't causing failures with the schnorrsig test?

Concept ACK

nice catch and good idea to extract a function 

edit: Ah, I didn't want to github-"approve". Anyway, we don't give attention to this.

> Did you look into why it wasn't causing failures with the schnorrsig test?

The reason is that in `ctime_test.c` we declassify public keys after creating them. In the case of the schnorrsig & extrakeys tests, they only operate on keypairs, and the public part of a keypair is declassified on `keypair_load` because it needs to branch on it.

events.message: ctime_test: move context randomization test to the end

issue.title: Add ECDSA adaptor signatures module
issue.body:
### Overview

This PR adds support for ECDSA adaptor signatures. It is based on the work of @jonasnick in https://github.com/jonasnick/secp256k1/pull/14.

### ECDSA Adaptor Signatures

This implementation conforms to the [DLC specification](https://github.com/discreetlogcontracts/dlcspecs/pull/114) and includes test vectors from the specification.

The specification is based on the [paper](https://github.com/LLFourn/one-time-VES/blob/master/main.pdf) "One-Time Verifiably Encrypted Signatures A.K.A. Adaptor Signatures" by @LLFourn. The idea was first proposed in a lightning-dev [post](https://lists.linuxfoundation.org/pipermail/lightning-dev/2019-November/002316.html).

### Python

I've [implemented](https://github.com/jesseposner/dlc/blob/master/ecdsa_adaptor.py) the specification in Python as well, which can be useful for testing purposes. [needs to be updated to match the latest spec revision]

comments.body: This must be left `0`. This is `main`. The issue here is valgrind exits with the exit code of the underlying process (unless there's a valgrind error, then we tell it to return 42). Successful runs will return 1 and that's why CI fails.
Since you're touching this anyway, can you `#include <stdlib.h>` (or simply `return 1` here)?
Oh and we also need `stdio` for `fprintf`.
